Risk Management Plan Executive Summary for The Dow Chemical Company, Pittsburg, California Site





Revision History:



14-Jul-2014 - Resubmitted RMP due to primarily to 5 year update requirement.  However, several changes are captured in this update as follows.

a) 310 Block Operations:

- Increase in chlorine inventory due to interconnectivity with other processes containing chlorine.  The 310 Block Operations does not have an inventory of chlorine above the Federal RMP threshold quantity (TQ) other than the connection.  But the interconnectivity results in chlorine present above TQ.  

- The facility is already, and remains, a Program 3 stationary source with accident prevention programs in place. 

b) 520 Block Operations:

- Reduction of anhydrous ammonia inventory below the Federal RMP TQ due to substantially smaller storage tank.

- Reduction of chlorine inventory, which is still above the RMP TQ, due to storage tanks taken out of service.

- Increase in anhydrous hydrogen chloride (aHCl) due to interconnectivy with other processes containing aHCl.  The 520 Block Operations does not have an inventory of aHCl above TQ other than the connection.  But the interconnectivity results in aHCl present above TQ.

- The facility is already, and remains, a Program 3 stationary source with accident prevention programs in place.

c) 560 Block Operations:

- Increase in chlorine inventory due to interconnectivity with other processes containing chlorine.  The 560 Block Operations does not have an inventory of chlorine above TQ other than the connection.  But the interconnectivity results in chlorine present above TQ.

- The facility is being now being declared as a Program 3 stationary source due to the connection, but it already had Program 3 accident prevention programs in place. 



15-Jul-2009 - Resubmitted RMP due to a) shutdown of 540 Block process, resulting in total removal of butadiene and acrylonitrile from the site as well as a reduction in aqueous ammonia inv

entory; b) removal of butadiene inventory from Site Logistics process as a result of the 540 Block process shutdown; and c) addition of anhydrous ammonia to 520 Block process, which will be introduced to the site in October, 2009.  Two incidents were removed from accident history, since they occurred more than 5 years ago.  Data elements were updated.  Removed butadiene and acrylonitrile scenarios, revised SO2 ARS and added ARS for anhydrous ammonia, but no changes to other WCS or ARS.



09-Apr-2007 - Resubmitted RMP due to shutdown of a unit and the startup of its replacement at 310 Block.  Data elements and SO2 ARS updated, but no change to other WCS or ARS or in accident history



28-Oct-2005 - Resubmitted RMP to reflect new regulated substance in existing facility and 2 new accidents in 5 year accident history.



21-Jun-2004 - Resubmitted RMP per 5 year update requirement.



2001 - Resubmitted RMP for new covered process at 310 Block.



1999 - Original RMP submission.





1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The Dow Chemical Company, Pittsburg, California site ("Dow Pittsburg") is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by Dow Pittsburg's comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at the Dow site in Pittsburg, California.  It is Dow Pittsburg's policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  Dow Pittsburg is also committed to responding to emergencies resulting from accidental releases in order to mitigate the release and any associated consequences.





2. The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled



The primary activity at Dow Pittsburg is agricultural chemical manufacturing.  Dow Pittsburg has six regulated substances present at the site.  These substances inc

lude ammonia (aqueous), ammonia (anhdyrous), chlorine, hydrogen chloride (anhydrous), hydrogen fluoride (anhydrous) and sulfur dioxide (anhydrous).  Ammonia (anhdyrous) is used in pollution control equipment for a boiler.  Ammonia (aqueous) is used in making an agricultural herbicidal intermediate.  Chlorine is used in making of intermediate and finished products for agricultural applications and is a byproduct of these processes.  Hydrogen chloride is made as a co-product of some of the agricultural product manufacturing processes.  Hydrogen fluoride and sulfur dioxide (anhydrous) are used to make agricultural products and intermediates.





3. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program



The Dow Pittsburg site has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR part 68 of the EPA.  The Dow Pittsburg site was designed and constructed in accordance with Dow Loss Prevention Principles and Dow Engineering Standards.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at the site.



Process Safety Information



Dow Pittsburg maintains detailed records of safety information that describe the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes. Examples include; Material Safety Data Sheets, piping and instrumentation diagrams, equipment specification sheets, reactive chemicals testing reports, and corrosion reports.  This information is regularly reviewed, as needed, and is readily acessible to plant operations personnel.



Process Hazard Analysis



Dow Pittsburg conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the covered processes are identified and effectively controlled.  The methodology used to carry out these analyses include Dow Fire and Explosion Index (F&EI), Dow Chemical Exposure Index (CEI), Reactive Chemical/Process Hazard Analysis (RC/PHA), Hazard and Operability Study (

HAZOP), Layers of Protection Analysis (LOPA), Reactive Chemical Reviews, and project Safety & Loss Prevention Reviews.  Studies utilize an appropriate team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering, maintenance and process operations and are revalidated on a regular basis.  Any findings related to the hazard analysis, where a response is required, are tracked to ensure resolution in a timely and appropriate manner.



Operating Procedures



For the purposes of safely conducting activities within Dow Pittsburg's covered processes, written operating procedures are maintained.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  This information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to plant operations personnel.



Training



Dow Pittsburg has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures and safe work practices associated with these processes.  Refresher training is provided at least once every 3 years, and more frequently as needed, for required process and safety topics.



Mechanical Integrity



Dow Pittsburg carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure safe and reliable operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, critical instruments, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps. Qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices are utilized to carry out appropriate maintenance.  These personnel are also offered specialized training as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.



Management of Change



Written procedures are in place at Dow Pittsburg to safely manage ch

anges in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification.



Pre-startup Reviews



Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted by appropriate personnel as a regular practice at Dow Pittsburg.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.



Compliance Audits



Dow Pittsburg conducts audits of compliance systems for RMP requirements on a regular basis.  These audits are carried out at least once every 3 years by a team of qualified personnel.  Any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are tracked to ensure resolution in a timely and appropriate manner.



Incident Investigation



Dow Pittsburg promptly and carefully investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring.  All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.



Employee Participation



Dow Pittsburg truly believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  The site has safety teams, which involve employees as leaders in facilitating team efforts. In addition, Dow Pittsburg employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular. Safe job performance is r

equired for each of the jobs at the site.



Contractors



Dow Pittsburg hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance, construction and various other activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out.  Dow Pittsburg has a policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the processes. Contractors are also required to inform Dow of any hazards they may introduce at the site. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.





4. Five-year Accident History



Dow Pittsburg has an excellent record of preventing accidental releases due to the site's release prevention policies.  There have been no accidents from Dow Pittsburg within the last 5 years with off-site or on-site impacts (deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place) that meet RMP reporting criteria.





5. Emergency Response Plan



Dow Pittsburg utilizes a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, sheltering-in-place, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.  To ensure proper functioning, Dow Pittsburg emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place that would require a modified emergency response.



CA Region II LEPC is the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) with which the emergency plan for the Dow Pittsburg site has been coordinated and verified. Dow Pittsburg also coordinates our plans and actions with local agencies and industrial mutual aid groups, which provide Dow Pittsburg with additiona

l emergency response capability.





6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Improving safety is a continuous process at Dow Pittsburg.  PHA's, Compliance Audits, Technology Reviews, Facility Self-Assessments and Management System Reviews, Incident Investigations, Emergency Response Drills and employee participation are a primary means for identifying opportunities to improve safety.  Structural seismic upgrades, materials of construction upgrades, installing additional process instrumentation and/or process controls, and conducting Hazard Awareness training are typical of currently planned changes to improve safety at the facility.  As another example of Dow Pittsburg's committment to continuous improvement in safety, the site was CalOSHA Voluntary Protection Plan (VPP) Star certified in January, 2013.





Additional information regarding process descriptions, Worst Case and Alternate Release Scenario impact maps, public receptors, etc., is available at the Dow Pittsburg Site.





The Dow Chemical Company

Pittsburg, California
